Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I glance at my phone between clients and see a text from my wife: “Laundry’s still waiting. Can you fold it tonight?” I know she’s been picking up the slack all week, and I promised I’d help more. Guilt prickles at me. But right now, I’m standing behind a new client, her eyes fixed on her reflection, lips pressed tight. She finally says, “It’s not quite what I pictured. Is it too late to fix the colour?” My heart sinks. I want to make her happy—my reputation depends on it. But my last appointment ran late, and I’m already behind. If I stay to redo her hair, I’ll get home even later, and the laundry will still be there, maybe with a side of disappointment from my wife. I feel pulled in two directions, both important, both demanding. My hands hover over the client’s hair, my mind racing, caught between the salon’s bright lights and the quiet promise I made at home.
